pages.transcription:
WEDNESDAY, June 6th, 1855.
Left St Louis at 12 O'clock M. on board Steamer "St. Mary" bound for Upper Missouri. -  
A rainy, cold morning - We called at the magazine to take one hundred kegs of powder - Our boat draws 18 inches light, is 600 tons berthed - has on now 250 long and draws 3 feet. -
She is a new boat and quite comfortable - 
We entered the Missouri River at 1/2 past four O'clock - Passed Belle Fontaine at 5 O'clock   still raining very fast - Stopped at 6 O'clock for the night, very dark
Conversed with Mr. Alex Culbertson until 1/2 past 12 O'clock - 
He has been 27 years in the Sioux and Blackfeet Country

THURSDAY, June 7th, 1855.
Beautiful, clear sky - 
Passed St Charles at 8 O'clock - river rising  Boat running very well 
- We have as passengers Col. A I. Vaughan + son, Alex Culbertson, Mr. Galpin, Col. A. Cumming and his secretary Mr. Roche - My friend Mr. Wilson + myself - 
Capt. of the boat, Le  Barge Chas. Chouteau clerk, and Doct. Robinson physician,
- The steamer "San Cloon" passed us this morning, we passed her about 9 O'clock, she was at a woodyard - She was in sight of us astern all day, and repassed us at 7 O'clock
As our boat is new, our Capt. will not press her -

Two very similar entries, one written directly on top of the other.
#1
FRIDAY, June 8th, 1855.
Retired last night at 10 O'clock boat laid by - Started on at 2 O'clock this morning but was compelled to lay by again on account of the fog which I found very dense when I arose at 1/2 past six O'clock -  
Cleared off and we started on again at 1/2 past seven - very pleasant day - Practiced shooting rifles for amusement - Col. Cumming brought 10 Sharps rifles with him - fired them very fun gun - throwing a ball an almost incredible distance. -
Passed the mouth of the "Osage" River at five O'clock, Passed "Jefferson City" at 7 O'clock and fifteen minutes,
The "Wm Baird" one of the boats purchased by the U.S to transport supplies to Fort Pierre passed us at 3 O'clock, two others in site astern -
#2
FRIDAY, June 8th, 1855.
Retired last night at 10 O'clock boat stopped for the night -
Started on at 2 O'clock this morning but was compelled to tie up a again on account of the fog which I found still very dense when I arose at 6 O'clock - It soon cleared off and we moved on - 
Col. Cumming brought 10 Sharps rifles with him and we amused ourselves today shooting at snags in the river -
Passed the mouth of the "Osage" River at 5 O'clock and Jefferson City at 7 O'clock 
The Wm Baird one of the boats purchased by government to transport supplies to Fort Pierre, passed us at 3 O'clock  2 others in sight astern

SATURDAY, June 9th 1855.
Another govt. boat passed us during the night - we travelled all night and are getting along finely - weather delightful - all in good health and spirits - except one of the men below who has fits, brought on by drinking too much - Passed "Boouville" at 7 O'clock A.M. - Passed "Glasgow" at 12 O'clock, M. 
The Captain shot a deer which was crossing the river, Killed him instantly, he sunk and we lost the venison - 
Slight shower about sun down - beautiful  rainbow - and magnificent sun set - prophecying a fine day tomorrow - Passed "Bushwick" at 7 O'clock A.M. - 
Cool delightful evening - A very bad river ahead full of snags and a few wind clouds were flying so the Capt. concluded to lay by

SUNDAY, June 10th 1855.
Another lovely morning, we laid by until 2 O'clock this morning - when we once more started on our winding way - and a winding way it is, - 
We over hauled, at 8 1/2 O'clock A.M, the "San Cloon" which passed us on the 7th and the "Wm Baird" U.S. which passed us on the 8th - both hard aground on a sand bar near "Hills Landing" - We went over without touching - 
Landed at "Lexington" at 1/2 past 3 O'clock P.M. Laid her one half hour - took in coal - 
Passed the day quietly and pleasantly - 
Men and passengers all in good health and weather delightful

MONDAY, June 11th 1855.
The weather still continuing clear and pleasant - 
We laid by again last night - The captain says it is best to risk nothing as we have so long a trip before us - Arose this morning at 7 O'clock - 
Three boats passed us last night while we were tied up. - 
Passed "Kansas City" at 2 1/2 O'clock - 3 Steamers in sight ahead - 
Landed at "Parkville" at 5 O'clock - Took on board Maj. Culbertson's wife and a daughter by another wife - very interesting family - 
Bad place in the river and the 3 boats that passed us last night we over hauled
written in left margin wrote letter

TUESDAY, June 12th, 1855.
Laid by last night and did not start until 7 O'clock this morning on account of fog - four boats in sight Wm Baird ahead - San Cloon and Arabia trying to get over the bar - 
Passed Leavenworth City at 8 1/2 O'clock - Passed the Fort at 9 O'clock - reached "Weston" at 10 1/2 O'clock, Landed Miss Culbertson and Doct C-, who are going to Illinois - also landed Col. Vaughan + son + Mr. Roche who are to get aboard again at St Jo. Joseph - Soon after leaving Weston, saw one old beaver and two young ones - 
We see indians occasionally along the banks - an evidence that we are gradually leaving civilisation -

WEDNESDAY, June 13th, 1855.
We stopped last evening earlier than usual, on account of being near St. Joseph and we did not wish to be troubled with people from the shore - Started at daylight and arrived at St. J. at 6 O'clock, stopped on the opposite side of the river - fine town but going fast into the river - 
We crossed in the yawl and procured a few stores, took Col. Vaughan, son + Mr. Roche on board again and were off about nine O'clock, passed the Iowa reserve - saw a good many indians along the shore - 
The appearance of this country is improving

THURSDAY, June 14th, 1855.
We laid by again last night but were off early this morning - passing the Nemaha reserve - 
A message arrived at St. Joseph, while Col. Vaughan was there, from Council Bluffs with a report that 100 emigrant waggons had been cut off and all men and women murdered, except one woman, who was spared by the indians, because she played an accordian - doubtful - shall learn the truth tomorrow at Council Bluffs - 
Stopped at dark for the night, found the no. of waggons had fallen to 13 - think when get to the Bluffs it will be none

FRIDAY, June 15th, 1855.
Started on at daylight this morning - delightful weather - expect to reach the Bluffs this afternoon - 
Opposite the Mouth of the "Platte" river at 1/2 past two O'clock P.M. - boat stopped - yawl out with eight across sounding for the channel, snags in every direction excessively hot - 
We started out and run up to "St Mary's" before dark, laid near shore at night - 
Sanfoy? says nothing in report that indians had robbed waggons, but says there is like to be trouble, as the indians have ordered traders to leave

SATURDAY, June 16th, 1855.
Got off early this morning, passed ""Bellevue" at 8 O'clock, after stopping at St Mary's sometime to chip ice +c. etc. Bellevue consists of one house, two barns, - We have had occasional glimpses of the prairies, but today we come in full view of immense prairies stretching away as far as the eye can reach - "Boundless + beautiful" -
We find the water very low, but as our boat draws very little water (3 ft) we do not have much trouble - passed old "Council Bluffs", former site of U.S. Fort, at five O'clock -

SUNDAY, June 17th, 1855.
We were compelled to stop early last night on account of a storm, The boat was well secured and it was well for us, as another storm came on at 1/2 past 3 O'clcok this morning - We got started at four O'clock run on until 1/2 past eight - stopped at "Soldier Creek" to wood, took on board 30 cords - 
Very fine morning, air cool and refreshing after the storm - 
Commenced getting rain about nine or ten O'clock and proved to be the hottest day we have had since we started -

MONDAY, Jnne 18th, 1855.
We tied up last night earlier than usual on account of a threatning black cloud in the North west. The storm came on very soon but did not pass directly over us - 
Retired about 11 O'clock - was aroused at 1/2 past 12 hearing Maj. Culbertson exclaim "Well we are going now" - looked out into the cabin and found the passengers nearly all up and under the impression that the boat was loose but it proved to be the yawl only - rain, hail, thunder, lightning and a perfect hurricane blowing, adding interest to the scene. - 
Passed "Blackbird's Hill" at 11 O'clock - met Mackinaw boats near this place at 1/4 of 12 O'clock.
They bring letters from traders above - the trader at "Fort Union says "I cannot get meat and wood although both are in sight of the fort". -

TUESDAY, June 19th, 1855.
Tied up last night opposite "Searjent's Bluff" (Floyd's Grove)
This was the site of an old govt. fort, long since demolished - A searjent, by the name of Floyd, settled here, died over 20 years since and was buried on top of the Bluff - hence the name - Mr. Galpin left us here to go to Fort Pierre by land in order to arrive before the boat, - we had another heavy gale last night - 
Met two more of the company's boats today - they are from "Fort Sarpy" on the Yellow Stone - 
They bring no further news - loaded with Buffalo robes -

WEDNESDAY, June 20th, 1855.
We stopped last night to cut wood for the first time - river rising fast - last evening we distributed some "Sharps" rifles cartridges +c. etc. - 
We are getting into the country of the "Poncahs" who are a detached band of Omaha's and said to be bad indians. - 
We passed an indian today - first Sioux - crossed out Pawnee we have seen he had a deer on his back which had evidently killed with his bow and arrow, as he had no other weapon - 
Passed "River au Jacques" at 5 O'clock - 
Slight shower at dark and is quite cool -- sudden change

THURSDAY, June 21st, 1855
We laid last night within three miles of the lower "Yancton" village - "Smutty Bear" chief - 
I arose at 1/2 past 4 O'clock we ran to the village - only about 20 lodges at home - had council - took chief and four men on board - shall leave them at the next "Yancton" village where the goods for the two bands will be distributed - found Mr. Galpin at "Smutty" "Bears" village, had not gained by taking land route - came on board again is to get off at next village - 
We passed "Poncah" village about 6 O'clock, near the mouth of "L'eau qui court" - river - saw some dead bodies on scaffold, also great number of graves

FRIDAY, June 22d, 1855.
We arrived at Yancton village at 1/2 past 12 O'clock passed "Town Rock" at 10 O'clock A.M. - 
Stopped at the indian village to distribute arrival presents from U.S. - The Chief is called "The man who struck the Ree" - fine looking men - most of them are large size -
A very pleasant day indeed - arrived at village 12 O'clock
While there a council was held and Col. Cumming gave them some good advice in regard to the course which it would be best for them to pursue the [[coming - crossed out] present summer. - left village at four O'clock

SATURDAY, June 23d, 1855.
We stopped about fifteen miles above the Indian Village last night - started on early this morning - cool and pleasant - no musquito yet - Our journey today was through a country almost destitute of timber - There being none upon the hills - immense prairies dotted with miniature mountains - 
saw one wolf - it is the first wild animal we have seen since we left Council Bluffs.
The water is falling but very slowly -
We will begin to find game again above Fort Pierre, and am told it is very plenty above fort Union.

SUNDAY, June 24th, 1855.
Clear, cool morning, but bids fair to be quite warm when the sun gets up - 
We tied up last night at the mouth of the "White River" or "White earth" as it is called on the maps - a very bad bar here but we crossed without much difficulty - 
About one O'clock today lost a man overboard - could not recover his body - Stopped about 11 O'clock at Cedar Island to take woods - at 1/2 past 1 O'clock passed portage of the Great bend of the Missouri - 30 miles around - 2 Miles across - 
Stopped to woods again and laid up for the night -

MONDAY, June 25th, 1855.
Another delightful morning, Boat started at 1/2 past 3 O'clock - Heard sound of the passengers complaining this morning of having been troubled by musquitos have not seen any myself - 
Passed by Fort Defiance, built by Choteau Chouteau, but since abandoned, at one O'clock P.M. - 
Very hot in the afternoon, indication of a storm but it passed over with only a few drops of rain - we are out of ice and are all looking forward anxiously to our arrival at Fort Pierre where we can get a new supply

TUESDAY, June 26th, 1855.
Laid up early last night at a cedar island, 40 miles from Fort Pierre Started early this morning but did not get along very rapidly on account of sand bars - 
Passed Fort George (Campbell + co) at 9 O'clock A.M. - 
Arrived at Fort Pierre at 1/2 past 3 O'clock P.M. This has been for many years a trading post of P. Chouteau + co's but was purchased this spring by the U.S. for 45,000. - for a garrison - timber is very scarce and the price fair for the post - enough - 
The company have about 300 head of cattle here and a great number of horses

WEDNESDAY, June 27th, 1855.
Fine cool morning
Col. Vaughan will distribute the annuity presents to the two Kettle bands of Sioux which will detain us all day probably - 
- After councilling a long time the indians refuse to receive their annuities, giving as a reason that they were afraid of the western indians, after another council with Col. Cumming who gave the two chiefs a medal each, they concluded to receive his goods, which they didÂ : also a part of a band of Yanktonais - 
We concluded our business and left Fort Pierre at 1/2 past three P.M. took a barge in tow on the opposite side of the river

THURSDAY, June 28th, 1855.
Clear, beautiful morning but bids fair to be the warmest day we have here - 
Thermometer stood a 98 yesterday at 11 O'clock - probably at about 106 in the afternoon
I was awakened this morning at daylight by some person on shore hallooing to the boat just as we were starting, it proved to be a squaw, mother of Mr. Hotekin's Hodgkin's wife who came on board at Fort Pierre - She said she came for her daughter - We did not stop - 
Passed the mouth of the big "Cheyenne" at 1/2 past 5 O'clock P.M. - 
Storm brewing and we tied up early - 
The day was not as hot as we anticipated

FRIDAY, June 29th, 1855.
A cool morning, fine is very comfortable - Started early but did not get a good distance before we stopped to wood and sent the yawl ahead to look out the channels. - Doct Hayden came on board at Fort Pierre, he is a young man who has been in this country for 2 years searching for curiosities in the way of birds, bugs, petrifactions +c. etc. - This country abounds in prickly pear - so that is almost impossible for a person unaccustomed to them to travel without getting the thorn in his foot - A cold day with an occasional sprinkle of rain - -

SATURDAY, June 30th, 1855.
This is one of the most unpleasant mornings since we left St Louis - cold + rainy. - We had a fire in the cabin yesterday and this morning the passengers are all crowding around the stove again -
Passed the mouth of the little Cheyenne before I was up - After running about 15 miles came to a sand bar extending across the river, sent the men ashore with the barge and they "cordelled" along shore three or four miles - The yawl was sent out to hunt for the channel, but as the report was unsatisfactory and the wind was blowing quite hard - we returned 
hard crossed out - all day

SUNDAY, July 1st, 1855.
One of the finest mornings since we left St Louis.
We started early - crossed the bar without trouble, crossed out - and took our barge in tow and steamed on up the river - 
Two hunters were sent ahead of the boat this morning - 
We picked them up about ten O'clock - they had killed only a prairie owl
-Passed the mouth of the "Nord" about 11 O'clock - soon after saw four crossed out - Elk antelope They were in sight some time (1/2 hour) curiosity greater than fear - Passed the mouth of the Grand River at 6 O'clock old Ree village at 7 - 
Very warm afternoon -

MONDAY, July 2d, 1855.
Fine morning but think it will be very warm - report indians in sight this morning, if true, they are probably Yanctonais who live in the vicinity of Long Lake near Cannon Ball River - Arrived at 11 O'clock at a few Yanctonais' lodges (12) planted corn - 
Col Vaughan made them a present after holding a council in which they expressed themselves friendly -
- Soon after leaving the village we discovered an immense column of smoke rising - it was a signal fire - the telegraph of the prairies - probably being for the purpose of informing hunters of presents -

TUESDAY, July 3d, 1855.
Pleasant morning, rather cool - Although yesterday morning we had every prospect of a very warm day - the weather changed before noon and we had a hail storm in the afternoon and the night was quite cool - Two deer were shot at yesterday from the boat + missed - 
Passed the mouth of Cannon Ball river at 1/2 past 1 -
Did not stop to examine, but were told by several on board who had been on the stream that round stones from which the river takes it's name could be picked up of different sizes varying from 3 feet Diameter to the size of a musket ball

WEDNESDAY, July 4th 1855.
Beautiful Morning - last night after the boat stopped went through a point of timber to the prairie - took four hours - got full of thorns - 
At the rising of the sun this morning a gun was fired in honor of the day - We often see the work of the Beaver along the banks - about noon passed the first vein of coal - 
Better Timber - 
The day is being celebrated quietly + pleasantly - had a very fine dinner, champagne, + other wines - We see a great many ducks, geese +c etc - Col Vaughan's interpreter killed a deer at a wooding place

THURSDAY, July 5th, 1855.
Cool night but a very pleasant morning, Had venison for breakfast
Arrived at the "Ree" village at 1/2 past 12 - 
Col V- Vaughan distributed the annual present - 
Left at 1/2 past 7 -
Ran on four miles to the Mandan village -
After distributing presents left at 10 O'clock in the evening -
Dwindled down, destroyed by diseases from larger nation to forty souls - Now number about 300 -
Singular people - blue eyes, yellow hair and grey?
We did not run far before stopping - for the night -

FRIDAY, July 6th, 1855.
Last  night was another cool night and this is another delightful morning
We left Mr. Hodgkins at Fort Clark - took on board Mr. Dawson of Ft Benton and four others - Bad news from Ft. Union - 
Yesterday saw a vein of coal at Ree village - 
Col. C- [[Cumming] sent two men from Ft. Pierre to the peaceful Sioux asking them to meet him at Ft. Clark nothing heard of men or indians, left order at Ft. Clark to send the men on to Fort Union if they come in soon - 
Wind commenced to blow very hard and we were obliged to lay up for the whole afternoon

SATURDAY, July 7th, 1855.
Very pleasant Morn - We arrived at Fort Berthold at nine O'clock A.M. - This is the "Gros Ventres" village or "Mintners"
They number about blank space where he intended to go back and write a number large men long hair caused by unclear - Col. V Vaughan distributed the presents
-Another coal vein here much thicker than at Ft. Clark - 
Left at 12 O'clock - 
We took on board three Blackfeet indians who had been here on a friendly visit also some Gros Ventres - 
One of the Blackfeet is named "Little Dog" and is the one whom Gov. Stevens mentions
A hunter started from Ft. Berthold -

SUNDAY, July 8th, 1855.
Windy but pleasant
-Buffalo were represented plenty in the vicinity and we are looking at the hills and prairies along the river anxious to get the first sight of them -
The winds blew us ashore about 12 miles below Knife River, here the first Buffalo were seen - 5 Bulls - 
The men shot a black tail deer, Mr. Chouteau went across the river to look for some Elk horns, met a grizzly and two cubs, did not shoot at her - 
Started on and found when we counted noses, that we had left six men who had strayed off - they had a long run -

MONDAY, July 9th, 1855.
Beautiful morning - saw a drove of fifty Elk and soon after breakfast the first Buffalo were in sight from the boat - 
We are constantly in sight of game - We gather quantities of Berries called Service berries - They are very delicious - I found a skull last night on the hills and some pieces of petrified wood
We are passing through a portion of the Marais river
See many veins of coal or lignite - 
Some prospect of getting to mouth of Yellow Stone tomorrow

TUESDAY, July 10th, 1855.
Beautiful morning again but quite warm - 
We got aground soon after breakfast and were detained about two hours had to spar off - 
We stopped to wood crossed out - about a few miles below the mouth of Muddy Creek, one of the men (unclear) went ashore and killed a fine fat bull - The boat stopped to get him - 
The warmest day for sometime - 
Passed Vermillon Hills before dark - 
Muddy R- River said to be the northern point

WEDNESDAY, July 11th, 1855.
Was awakened this morning by the boy asking if I wanted to see a buffalo killed - 
Got up and found a small drove, thirty or forty, in the river - 
We caught 8 calves and took on board the carcases of two yearling bulls 1 Heifer and one old cow - about 8 O'clock came in eight of an immense herd grazing upon the bluff - I shot 2 dead and wounded one - 
Passed the mouth of the Yellow Stone and arrive at Ft Union at 7 O'clock

THURSDAY, July 12, 1855.
We could not land at the Fort, stopping on the opposite side - Water very low - Cool morning - The fort is built of wood with two stone bastions - about five miles above the mouth of the Y.S. Yellowstone River - 
The boat is unloading today crossed out - and the river unclear about the Fort presents quite a lively appearance boats crossing +c. etc. -
Not an indian lodge in sight - 
Not very well -

FRIDAY, July 13th, 1855.
A slight shower of rain this morning but soon cleared off - 
The steamboat is preparing to get off - 
Will leave about noon - The appearance upon the side of the river where the Fort stands is materially changed - 
When yesterday there was not a soul today at ten O'clock stood 350 lodges of Assiniboins containing about 3500 souls - Took dinner on the steamboat and took leave of the officers of the boat, and Mr. Roche who returns from here, being disgusted with the trip in prospection, and crossed over to the Fort

SATURDAY, July 14th, 1855.
Last night we had a very heavy rain, accompanied with wind & thunder - 
We were met very kindly by the "Fur Comp." people at the Fort. The indians are lounging about the Fort outside and within - 
Col. Cumming has concluded to go by land to Ft. Benton - Mr. Wilson and myself go by water - a long tedious trip - 
The boats are loading up on the opposite side of the river - A slight sprinkle of rain about dark - accompanied by thunder and lightning -

SUNDAY, July 15th, 1855.
Sunday at Fort Union has been only observed by late rising and only two meals of victuals, every thing else went on as usual on account of the desire to start the boats as soon as possible - 
The Indians have been dancing nearly all day in the fort - 
No particular difference in the dance from other nations I have seen - it wound up with a buffalo dance, which is very much like the others except the dancers wear the skin of a buffalo head - 
Weather quite cool towards night

Beautiful morning - did not sleep very well on account of the howling of the dogs, of which there are a great number about the Fort. They are of the Esquimeaux Breed introduced by the Assiniboins who got them from Red River indians - The Ass. are poor in horses but high in dogs - 
Mr. Meldrum is here he is a Scotchman by birth - A Crow by adoption of which nation he is a chief - he has been in the country about thirty years - is a very intelligent man about fifty years of age - 
Boats are nearly ready to leave - will get off tomorrow

TUESDAY, July 17th, 1855.
Fine morning, rather cool.
The boats are loaded and we will get off today - 
We left Fort Union at 12 O'clock precisely, went about 1 1/2 miles and stopped at 2 O'clock to dine - Started on at three - 
Got aground once before dinner which detained us sometime - 
We ran on till dark when we stopped for the night - We have four hunters out - Two on each side of the river
They came in tonight with one deer, killed another which they hung up to keep it out of the way of the wolves

WEDNESDAY, July 18th, 1855.
Fine cool morning - 
We are two boats the crew of the larger one (80 tons) on which I am a passenger consists of 39 men on the cordelle - 2 cooks - 4 men with poles - 1 pilot and one supercargo - The men of the other is 24 men on cordelle, 2 cooks, 2 men with poles, 1 capt. and 1 supercargo  - 
Last night 4 men deserted from the other boat and two from ours The hunters came in to breakfast with one deer, the other eaten by crossed out - the wolves a Bear. - 
We did not make much progress - stopped early to re/model the steering oar

THURSDAY, July 19th, 1855.
Beautiful Warm morning, We have plenty of veinson now and expect to get Buffalo soon - we are not far enough from the fort yet - 
Started on early - sent a man back to the fort with letters also for tools as it is the opinion of the managers that we are so heavily laden it will be necessary to build a boat - Men returned from the fort in afternoon bringing various tools which we had sent for - 
Stopped early - went out hunting a short distance saw nothing but tracks

FRIDAY, July 20th, 1855.
Fine morning - quite warm - our hunters left the boat early, came in to breakfast with an elk - All of them had been on one side this morning We crossed two with three (3) horses on the opposite side - Bluffs nearly the same here as below - White stone (sand with an occasional vein of lignite - and wide? brick stone - Water is getting clearer - Squaws went on shore and brought on board quantity of round balls like marbles - also some yellow crossed out - goosebe currants
I left the boat after dinner with my friend Mr. Wilson, after walking 2 miles I saw a Bull back on the prairie - killed him, went out for it from boat + found the hunters had dressed it - hot - saw a beaver? hill -

SATURDAY, July 21st, 1855.
Lovely morning. The hunters on the left bank brought in two Antelope last night - had some of the liver for breakfast - Man caught a large rattlesnake 11 rattles - 
Hunting killed a buffalo bull today and one antelope.
The man in charge says we came about 18 miles yesterday - 
I went a short distance but saw no game, picked up several round balls similar to those found on Cannon ball river - 
This is the warmest day since we left Fort Union -

SUNDAY, July 22d, 1855.
Another beautiful morning with prospect of a warm day, We stopped to breakfast about one mile below the mouth of the Big Muddy, After breakfast we went on a few hundred yards and made a short stop at some old wintering houses, I went ashore with my glass and discovered smoke in a point above mouth of Big Muddy, supposed to be indians as the crossed out - men hunters report having seen sign yesterday - 
Saw a buffalo Bull in the mire on the opposite side of the river
Mr. Wilson, Doct H- Hayden + myself took the yawl and crossed to him - he ws very poor and we did not disturb him

MONDAY, July 23d, 1855.
Last night we were troubled with musquitoes for the first time - 
The hunters on the right bank came in with one common + 1 Black tail deer last night - the others we have not heard from at 10 O'clock this morning the last we saw of them they brought us six young geese yeasterday noon which they had killed with sticks - 
The hunters on the left bank came in after noon with 1 Beaver Deer +c etc. had met with no accident, merely missed the boat last night - 
The others killed 3 Bulls and two deer today. We have plenty of meat but would like to see buffalo more plenty -

TUESDAY, July 24th, 1855.
Musquitoes last night
Yesterday was a very hot day. The hottest since we left the Fort, and this morning has every appearane of being the forerunner of a still more oppressive one - We are going from 10 to 15 miles per day - 
Doct. Hayden went ashore at Chardon's? Creek and reporteed Buffalo in sight, I went off with Mr. Wilson but did not get any as they crossed the river before we reached them, The hunters killed 5 cows on one bank and 6 on the other - 
At dark a light sprinkle of rain - 
Made a very poor run today

WEDNESDAY, July 25th, 1855.
No musquitoes last night, slept very well, At ten O'clock we stopped to build a boat, our boats are drawing too much water and we are compelled to unite another out of green timber - It is a fine cool morning and prospect of a very pleasant day - One of the men caught a young beaver just before stopping, I have been watching him eat - he is a very intelligent looking little fellow - 
The large boat was unloaded today - saws filed and other preparation made for boat building

THURSDAY, July 26th, 1855.
We put up a sort of a tent last night, composed of six forks covered with a cloth used in the boats for covering the goods - soon after we had it arrayed the winds raised and came near blowing it away - 
The wind blew for an hour - And this morning it is quite cool - The hunters went out before breakfast and killed one elk and one anteloope, we sent a man across the river to place a letter on the route Col. Cumming is supposed to travel, to inform him of our situation - The hunters brought in today 5 cows, 1 Elk, 2 deer and 1 antelope - I went 2 or three miles from camp - saw 3 Buffalo and 3 Elk Killed nothing
